section-block.rac_essential-question: How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?

section-block.rac_book_caption: Book: Penguin Day: A Family Story

section-block.rac_book_summary: Baby penguin is hungry! While mama penguin hunts for food, papa penguin stays with his baby. Can papa keep baby safe? Does mama get baby’s food?

section-block.rac_body-text: Use Ss and Tt Alphabet Cards.
section-block.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Show all the pictures. Say: S is for sun. I spy the sun. Who can show me what I spy? Continue. Then show all the letters and play “I Spy.”

section-block.rac_body-text: To the tune of “I’m a Little Teapot:”I’m a little penguin, short and stout I play with friends; I waddle about. Mama looks for seafood while I wait. Papa helps to shoo danger away.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Penguin Day by Nic Bishop.
Pablo enjoys reading informational texts about animals, especially penguins!
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready? Why does mama penguin take a journey to the sea?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: I see a group of mama penguins. Why do you think they’re going to travel together?
Mama penguin is looking for food for baby penguin. What do you see on this page?
I see the letter s in the word sleepy. Who can come point to the s in sleepy?
The mama penguins are going home. What did the mama penguins do on their journey?
Now I can see what a skua is! Why do you think papa penguin scares the skua away?
I see the letter t in the word tired. Who can come point to the letter t in tired?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question: Why does mama penguin take a journey to the sea?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
Write and read aloud a short sentence describing how penguin parents help their babies.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does mama penguin get food for baby penguin?
Mama penguin goes on a journey to get f____ (food).
Mama penguin goes on a journey to get food.
What kind of food does mama penguin get in the sea?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Encouraging children to ask questions nurtures children’s natural curiosity. When children ask questions after learning new ideas, show an active interest in their questions. Providing children with simple explanations can lead to more questions which can lead to rich discussions.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Identify and Solve Problems
section-block.rac_body-text: Start a discussion about problem-solving, by saying, Sometimes we have problems that we need to solve. Then share a time when you had a simple problem such as losing an item and how you solved the problem. Encourage children to share when they had a problem. Help children name problems they might face in their day.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to use our problem-solving Mind Builder as we revisit the book Penguin Day by Nic Bishop.
When Clifford has a problem, he looks for ways to solve his problem. Let’s see what problems mama penguin, papa penguin, and baby penguin have and how they solve their problems.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
Read aloud the book and the Day 2 prompts.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Baby penguin is hungry! Look at the mama and papa penguin.
What problem do the adult penguins have? (MB)
The mama penguins reach the sea but see scary animals. Why is this a problem for the mama penguins? (MB)
How did the mama penguins communicate to solve the problem of the scary animals? (MB)
Now we see that baby penguin is in danger. That’s another problem! How does papa penguin keep baby penguin safe? (MB)
How did mama and papa penguin help each other feed baby penguin? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Have children use problem-solving by having them work together in groups to create connecting towers. Challenge them to see how they can build their towers without the towers falling down. If their tower falls, ask the group what they can do differently to build their tower. If their tower is too low, ask the group what they can do to make the tower taller.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about penguin babies.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Toys and other manipulatives help children make connections to the real world. Children can identify and solve problems like figuring out how to balance blocks or building a tower without falling. Children can practice their problem-solving skills in a tactile and concrete way.

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask children what they know about penguins. Use the book’s photos to show that penguins are birds that have adapted to their environment.
Have children stand up and pretend to be penguins. Show them how to rock side-to-side in a “waddle” movement. Have children fold their arms into “flippers.”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the informational text Penguin Day by Nic Bishop.
The book Penguin Day tells us about rockhopper penguins. Pablo loves learning fun facts about penguins.
This is the guiding question that I want you to think about as we read: What do penguin parents do to feed and protect their babies?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions. Have conversations with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Mama penguin waddles to the sea to get food. Let’s clap out each syllable in the word waddles.
Mama penguin swims in cold waters with big waves. What do you see mama penguin doing?
Papa penguin’s job is to keep an eye on baby penguin. Why does papa penguin need to keep an eye on baby penguin?
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Revisit keep an eye on Card.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Papa penguin scares off the skua. How do you know papa penguin is brave?
Mama penguin is back with her family! What do you see on this page?

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question: What do penguin parents do to feed and protect their babies?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Mama gets food for the baby.
Mama takes a journey to the sea and catches fish.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to describe and write about how penguin parents help their babies.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does baby penguin get food from mama penguin?
Baby penguin gets food from m________ (mama) penguin.
Baby penguin gets food from mama penguin.
How does papa penguin protect baby penguin?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: When children explore the world around them, they begin to develop their observational skills. When children ask “why” animals behave in certain ways, they are building curiosity and strengthening their learning. Teaching children about animals is an opportunity to let them become cognizant learners and beginner behaviorists.

section-block.rac_body-text: Tell children they’ll be reading about a new animal family today. Just like in Penguin Day, mama hen cares for her chicks.
Use the song “Old MacDonald Had a Farm” and have children specifically sing about chicks and what the chicks say.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to sing a song. It’s about a mother hen who feeds and protects her chicks.
Pablo loves to learn about how animal babies learn, live, and grow! “The Chicks Say ‘Pio, Pio, Pio’” explains how a mother hen helps her chicks eat, live, and grow.
Penguin Day and “The Chicks Say ‘Pio, Pio, Pio’” show how animal parents help their babies eat, live, and grow. Let’s see what’s the same about these two texts!
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about our concept question: How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart; then use these prompts to read and discuss the child-facing poster together. Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to take turns responding.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: In this first picture, I see mama hen has many chicks. How can we tell how many chicks mama hen has?
section.rac_body-text: Point to the words, left to right, and model reading the words.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Mama hen feeds her chicks. How does mama hen feed her chicks?
How does mama hen give her chicks shelter?
Now the chicks are awake. They want more food. What do you think mama hen will do next?

section.rac_body-text: Sing or play a recording of the song, and lead children to imitate the chicks when they are cold (have them wrap their arms around themselves and shiver) and by using their arms as wings (third stanza).
Provide a writing prompt about an animal family who helps their baby and guide children’s responses.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Sharing Spanish onomatopoeias along with English ones is a fun and easy way to help all children make connections between different languages. Teaching animal sounds using onomatopoeia can help multilingual learners understand how even animal sounds have unique words. In English, owls say hoo-hoo, but in Spanish they saw uu uu.

section-block.rac_body-text: Have children pretend they are mama penguins. Have them waddle in place. Ask children to pretend to dive into the water and then have them make swimming motions as they search for food for baby penguin.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to act out the book Penguin Day by Nic Bishop.
Remember, this book is an informational text. An informational text tells about real things. This book is about real penguin families. Pablo loves to read informational texts and learn about animals!

This week we read about a penguin family—mama, papa, and baby penguin. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question: If you were mama penguin, what would your journey for food be like?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s pretend we are baby penguins. We are hungry. How can we communicate that we are hungry?
Let’s pretend we are mama penguin on our journey to the sea. Let’s scamper down hills, climb down cliffs, and hop across sand!
What do you think might be hard about mama penguin’s journey? What do you think might be easy?
Who can point to the skua? Why is the skua scary?
Why do you think the penguins are happy to see each other? Let’s pretend we’re happy penguins and waddle about!
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question: If you were mama penguin, what would your journey for food be like?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I would travel with other mama penguins.
I would look for fish and krill.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about how animal and human parents take care of their babies.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Would you jump in the ocean?
I would j_______ (jump) in the ocean.
I would jump in the ocean.
How is mama penguin’s day the same as papa penguin’s day? How is it different?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children love to read about animals, especially baby animals. Teaching children about the responsibilities of parenthood and how babies learn and grow helps children understand that they too have a lot to learn. Showing children how difficult it is to keep a baby safe and fed helps to foster empathy for their own caregivers.
